Team4180.Input

Class Attack3Joystick

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.GenericHID
      • edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Joystick
        • Team4180.Input.Attack3Joystick
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IDevice, IInputOutput

    public class Attack3Joystick
extends Joystick
    Represents a Logitech Attack3 joystick. This is the joystick that came with the 2012 KOP. We extend the Joystick class that comes with the FIRST Java library because we still need the functions it provides to detect buttons and joystick axis positions.
    Since:
    2013

    • Nested Class Summary

      static class  Attack3Joystick.Button
      Type safe enumeration class representing all the buttons on the Joystick.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void addButtonListener(Attack3Joystick.Button[] buttons, ButtonListener listener) 
      void addButtonListener(Attack3Joystick.Button button, ButtonListener listener)
      When you want to have code respond to a button press, create a new ButtonListener class that responds to the button being pushed down, and released.
      void addJoystickListener(JoystickListener listener)
      When you want to have code respond to joystick movement, create a new JoystickListener class that responds to the joystick moving in any direction Example: addJoystickListener(new JoystickListener() { public void joystickMoved(double x, double y, double z) { // Now, what do we do when the button is released? } });
      void listen()
      Repeatedly call this method to check for a button press and notify the listeners for those buttons.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Attack3Joystick

        public Attack3Joystick(int port)
        Creates a new instance of the Logitech Attack3 joystick. This is the joystick that can with the 2012 KOP.
        Parameters:
        port - the port that this joystick is plugged in to

    • Method Detail

      • listen

        public void listen()
        Repeatedly call this method to check for a button press and notify the listeners for those buttons.

      • addButtonListener

        public void addButtonListener(Attack3Joystick.Button button,
                     ButtonListener listener)
        When you want to have code respond to a button press, create a new ButtonListener class that responds to the button being pushed down, and released. Example: addButtonListener(Button b, new ButtonListener() { public void buttonUp() { // Now, what do we do when the button is released? } public void buttonDown() { // Now, what do we do when the button is pushed? } });
        Parameters:
        button - the Button to listen to
        listener - the "listener" that responds to the button being pressed or released

      • addButtonListener

        public void addButtonListener(Attack3Joystick.Button[] buttons,
                     ButtonListener listener)

      • addJoystickListener

        public void addJoystickListener(JoystickListener listener)
        When you want to have code respond to joystick movement, create a new JoystickListener class that responds to the joystick moving in any direction Example: addJoystickListener(new JoystickListener() { public void joystickMoved(double x, double y, double z) { // Now, what do we do when the button is released? } });
        Parameters:
        listener - the "listener" that responds to the joystick moving
